comment_body.17:
Location: Denver, CO

Price range: 35.5k or ~590/month

Lease or Buy: Buy/finance

New or used: New or CPO 2019 model

Type of vehicle: Crossover/subcompact/SUV

Must haves: AWD, Spacious room for a large dog in the back seat + luggage/cargo, tow hitch factory/dealer installed, remote start, Apple CarPlay

Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Auto

Intended use: My daily driver, mine and my girlfriends weekend car for trips to the mountains, project runs to Home Depot, road and camping trips.

Vehicles you've already considered:

  • 2019 Ford Escape Titanium

  • 2020 Subaru Crosstrek Limited

  • 2020 Subaru Outback Onyx XT

  • 2019 Subaru Outback 3.6R Touring CPO

Is this your 1st vehicle: No

Do you need a Warranty: No for Ford, but if a Subaru i've heard good things about their gold plus plan.

Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: No

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes: My girlfriend and I recently moved to Denver, CO. We both drive a 2015 Ford Focus SE and a 2016 Ford Focus Titanium respectively. My parents are looking to purchase my car from me and we would be looking at getting some AWD vehicle that would be my daily driver and then we'd use it for any road or camping trips, transport home depot or craigslist finds for her DIY projects around the apartment, etc. We would just mostly be transporting ourselves and our two dogs (1 small, 1 large) and have no plans on having children. Every once in a while we have family or friends come out and visit so a roomy back row would be nice, but absolutely do not need anything large than a 5-seater.

My dad works for Ford and as such I get A-Plan pricing which usually knocks a few Gs off the dealer price and I get 0-1.9% APR financing. However, my girlfriend and I have had very bad experiences with our Focus's transmissions and Sync 3 in our cars. I don't mind getting another Ford, but I am hesitant to as of now. I've driven Ford my entire life and the prospect of getting something new and different in a Subaru is very enticing.

The 2020 Subaru Crosstrek looks like a good inexpensive AWD replacement. I have a friend who loves his and recommended I look at one. However, he said his doesn't have much power under the hood and driving up in the mountains when it snows it struggles a bit. I like the size, price, and features of the Crosstrek, but the lack of horsepower concerns me.

The 2020 Subaru Outback Onyx XT looks like a car I'd absolutely love and have fun driving and using during the week and on weekends. It'd be big enough for us to camp in the back and have plenty of space for the dogs or if friends/family come to visit and we're driving them around. It has the turbo engine, non-leather waterproof interior, 11.6" infotainment, all the safety bells and whistles, and checks all of my boxes and then some. It's a little pricey and at the top of my budget, but after hours of reading and watching youtube videos it looks like a really fun and solid vehicle.

There is a CPO 2019 Subaru Outback 3.6R Touring that has caught my eye at the same dealership. I has ~5k miles, the carfax shows it had a windshield replacement and then went on sale a few days ago and that's really it. With this, I believe i'd be getting more car for my money since it would be CPO.

I plan on going to test drive those four cars this week, but figured I'd get some opinions here in case there's anything I missed in my research or feedback on my list. TIA.

comment_body.21:
Anyone have personal experience with Fords 1.0 liter ecoboost?

I’ve been keeping an eye out for a new daily driver for what seems like two years now. My grand marquis just isn’t cutting it anymore. I want something more fun and with more usable space again (not a sedan basically).

I keep an eye out for manual hatchbacks mostly in my area. I’ve test driven a few Fiesta ST but I’d feel bad if I bought one of those with the intent to daily drive and pull the rear seats out of for more space. There is very rarely manual S or SE models around me for sale used but an SE popped up at a local dealer. It’s a 2016 Fiesta SE but it was optioned with the 1.0 ecoboost engine. I don’t honestly know much about those, I was primarily looking into the good old 4 banger, low tech, reliable engines.

I know spec wise the 3 cylinder ecoboost is actually more potent than the 4 cylinder model but how is the reliability of it? You’re adding a turbo, changing to direct inject, I assume parts are far less available than just the base engine. The price and mileage on it is ludicrously low. They’re asking $9900 and it’s only done 22k miles.
